name: Women's Labor: Paid, Unpaid, and Undervalued

chapters.name: The History of Women's Work
topics: How was women's unpaid household labor in colonial America essential yet invisible in economic accounting?
What obstacles did the 'Lowell mill girls' face when organizing in the 1830s and 1840s?
Why did wages fall as teaching and nursing became feminized professions in the late 19th century?
How did 'Rosie the Riveter' prove women could do 'men's work'—then get pushed out when the war ended?
What did the women's movement of the 1960s and 1970s demand, and what has changed since?
Why does the gender pay gap persist despite women becoming the majority of college graduates?

chapters.name: The Cult of Domesticity and the 'Working Woman'
topics: What was the 'cult of domesticity' and how did it justify excluding women from education, professions, and politics?
Why was the domestic ideal always a middle-class standard that poor women and women of color could never attain?
How did the ideology persist even as women entered the workforce during industrialization?
What was Betty Friedan's 'problem that has no name' in The Feminine Mystique?
Why do working mothers today face criticism that working fathers rarely encounter?
How does the cult of domesticity survive in expectations about who should sacrifice career for family?

chapters.name: Women and the Labor Movement
topics: Why did AFL craft unions typically exclude women or relegate them to auxiliary roles?
What was the 'Uprising of the 20,000' and what did the 1909 shirtwaist makers' strike achieve?
How did the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire of 1911 galvanize support for workplace safety and unionization?
Why did women's organizing often take different forms—mutual aid societies, boycotts, community campaigns?
How did the postwar labor movement become male-dominated and focused on male breadwinners?
What role does the Coalition of Labor Union Women play in bringing feminist perspectives to labor?

chapters.name: The Gender Pay Gap: Causes and Controversies
topics: Why do women earn 82 cents for every dollar men earn, and why is the gap larger for women of color?
How does occupational segregation explain part of the pay gap—and why do wages decline when women enter a field?
What portion of the pay gap reflects direct discrimination that economists cannot explain away?
What is the 'motherhood penalty' and why do mothers' earnings decline while fathers' earnings increase?
What role do resume studies play in demonstrating bias in hiring and salary offers?
What policy approaches—pay transparency, family-friendly policies, challenging segregation—could close the gap?

chapters.name: Occupational Segregation: Pink Collar and Blue Collar
topics: Why does nursing remain 87% female, teaching 77% female, while construction is 97% male?
How did certain jobs become coded as 'women's work' through assumptions about nimble fingers and pleasant voices?
What research shows that wages decline when occupations shift from male to female—and vice versa?
Why have nursing wages been historically suppressed despite demanding skills and life-or-death responsibilities?
What challenges do women face when breaking into male-dominated fields like construction, firefighting, or tech?
Why is revaluing work that women do as important as integrating male-dominated occupations?

chapters.name: The Maternal Penalty
topics: Why is becoming a mother, economically, the worst career decision a woman can make?
What experimental studies show about discrimination against mothers in hiring and salary offers?
Why do fathers experience a wage premium while mothers experience a wage penalty?
How does the penalty vary by class and race, with single mothers particularly disadvantaged?
What factors beyond reduced hours explain the motherhood penalty?
What policies—paid leave, affordable childcare, flexible work—could reduce the motherhood penalty?

chapters.name: Unpaid Domestic Labor
topics: How much is unpaid household labor worth annually—and why is it invisible in GDP calculations?
Why do women do far more housework than men even when both work full-time outside the home?
What is the 'second shift' and why does the gendered division persist across generations?
What is the 'mental load'—remembering appointments, planning meals, tracking supplies—and who carries it?
How does women's disproportionate domestic labor constrain their options in paid work?
What would it take to change the division of domestic labor beyond individual negotiation?

chapters.name: Care Work: The Crisis Economy
topics: Why do care workers who perform society's most essential labor earn poverty wages of $13-14 per hour?
How do the demographics of care work—women, women of color, immigrants—reflect broader inequality?
Why do the economics of care create a structural problem where neither families nor workers can afford it?
How did the COVID-19 pandemic expose the care crisis through childcare closures and nursing home deaths?
How do Scandinavian and European countries invest in care as a public good?
What would it mean to pay care workers what their work is actually worth?

chapters.name: Domestic Workers: Nannies, Housekeepers, and Exclusion
topics: Why were domestic workers explicitly excluded from the NLRA, FLSA, and other New Deal labor protections?
How did the exclusion reflect the racial composition of domestic work and Southern Democratic demands?
What consequences of that historical exclusion persist today in lack of protections?
How does immigration status compound vulnerability to abuse, wage theft, and harassment?
What has the National Domestic Workers Alliance achieved since its founding in 2007?
How have state-level 'Domestic Workers' Bills of Rights' extended protections in some jurisdictions?

chapters.name: Sexual Harassment in the Workplace
topics: How did the women's movement first name sexual harassment and develop legal theories against it?
What are the two forms of sexual harassment—quid pro quo and hostile work environment—under Title VII?
What did Anita Hill's testimony during the Thomas hearings reveal about how hard it is to be believed?
What did the #MeToo movement achieve, and what are its limits for non-celebrity workers?
Why do non-disclosure agreements and mandatory arbitration hide harassment and protect harassers?
What structural changes beyond individual accountability—unions, transparency, banning NDAs—could end harassment?

chapters.name: Family Leave and Work-Life Policy
topics: Why is the United States alone among wealthy nations in not guaranteeing paid family leave?
What does the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 provide, and why is unpaid leave no leave at all?
How do Canada, Germany, and Nordic countries provide far more generous paid leave?
Why is American policy a patchwork where a handful of states have enacted paid leave programs?
How does the lack of gender-neutral leave policies that encourage fathers intensify the motherhood penalty?
Why do proposals for federal paid leave repeatedly fail despite the obvious costs of the status quo?

chapters.name: The Pandemic and Women's Work
topics: Why was the COVID-19 economic downturn called a 'she-cession' with women's employment falling more sharply?
How did school closures and childcare disruptions push mothers out of the workforce?
What risks did essential workers—disproportionately women of color—face for poverty wages?
What crushing burdens did healthcare workers, especially nurses, face during the pandemic?
Why has the recovery been uneven, with many women who left not returning to the workforce?
Will the pandemic's demonstration that the economy cannot function without care translate into lasting policy change?
